ThingDef.label: synthetic donkey
ThingDef.description: Something is strange about this donkey...

ThingDef.label: synthetic buck
ThingDef.description: Something is strange about this buck...

ThingDef.label: synthetic cougar
ThingDef.description: One of the most dangerous big cats, cougars are solitary hunters with long, sharp teeth and claws. They stalk prey from hidden positions before pouncing.\n\nWhile humans are not their normal diet, they won't turn down a meal of vulnerable human meat.

ThingDef.label: synthetic bear
ThingDef.description: Something is strange about this buck...

ThingDef.label: synthetic rat
ThingDef.description: Something is strange about this rat...

ThingDef.label: synthetic hare
ThingDef.description: Something is strange about this hare...

ThingDef.label: synthetic megasloth
ThingDef.description: Something is strange about this megasloth...

ThingDef.label: synthetic squirrel
ThingDef.description: One of the many hardy rodent species that follows humankind everywhere it spreads. Squirrels are distinguished by their bushy tails, which they use as umbrellas in bad weather.

ThingDef.label: synthetic warg
ThingDef.description: Heavily-muscled wolf-like creatures with vicious unnatural claws and an absurdly powerful bite. They will only eat meat or corpses. If disturbed in the wild, they are very likely to attack.\n\nScientists say wargs are the descendants of weaponized military animals created for population suppression. The superstitious see them as the tools of an angry god.

ThingDef.label: synthetic raccoon
ThingDef.description: A small, hardy animal that ranges wide across forests and shrubland. It is happy to break into your garbage container, or your kitchen, to eat almost anything.

ThingDef.label: synthetic wild boar
ThingDef.description: This hairy omnivore is descended from escaped pigs and evolved for living in the wild.\n\nIts tusks make it a better fighter than its domesticated pig cousins. Unfortunately, it is too unruly to be trained in the most complex tasks.

ThingDef.label: synthetic rhinoceros
ThingDef.description: Despite being herbivorous, this large mammal is very easy to enrage. Once angered, its massive strength and sharp horn make it a brutal opponent. It has more muscle in one leg than most humans do in their whole body.

ThingDef.label: synthetic fox
ThingDef.description: Something is strange about this fox...

ThingDef.label: synthetic ibex ram
ThingDef.description: The wild ancestor of the domesticated goat. Ibexes live on marginal territory where most antelopes couldn't survive, eating lichens and sparse mountain plants. They're famous for dextrously hopping across bare cliff faces - and for their violent ramming attack.

ThingDef.label: synthetic turkey
ThingDef.description: A short, fat, flightless bird known for its hilarious 'gobbling' call. It has been long domesticated, but also lives in the wild.

ThingDef.label: gazelle
ThingDef.description: A small, extremely quick antelope known for its amazingly long leap.

ThingDef.label: synthetic lynx
ThingDef.description: A wildcat larger than a housecat, but smaller than a cougar. Lynxes survive on a diet of small birds and animals. Their very warm fur keeps them safe from the brutally cold temperatures of their frozen territories.

ThingDef.label: synthetic wolf
ThingDef.description: A rugged predator long feared by many ancient Earth cultures. As pack hunters, wolves have complex social lives and are fiercely intelligent.

ThingDef.label: synthetic muffalo
ThingDef.description: A large herding herbivore descended from buffalo and adapted for both cold and warm environments. While enraged muffalo are deadly, tamed muffalo are quite docile and can be used as pack animals.\n\nNobody is quite sure why they're blue - it might even be some early genetic modification test that just never got changed.

ThingDef.label: synthetic iguana
ThingDef.description: These large lizards normally feed on plant matter. However, when angered, their tough hide and sharp claws make them quite dangerous.\n\nResting iguanas hold their heads high, giving them an amusing 'proud' look. But they're not proud; they're just trying to see predators so they don't get eaten.

ThingDef.label: synthetic capybara
ThingDef.description: The largest natural rodent, the capybara is well-adapted for steaming jungle environments.
